docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: • This individual datasheet was designed as one of four parts that will make up the final product in this EGR304 course. This GitHub contains most of the entire development process for this individual component.

docs.title: Project Summary
docs.text:
This project aims to assist in the separation and organization of trash in homes and selected locations. This individual design helps this project by processing the weight of the trash and transforming that value into a visual representation for the user.

team report.

docs.title: My Contribution
docs.text: In this Team assignment, I designed the main section of the LED Scale subsystem involving the force sensor. To review the details about how this individual project works together with the other three projects go to "EGR 304 Team 207 Report"

docs.title: Component Selection Example
docs.text:
Table 1: Force sensor

Internal Weight limit module

Solution Pros Cons Option 1. Capacitive Force Sensor 8 mm 100 N (22 lbs)$37.50/eachlink to product *Inexpensive* Fall within the weight limits* Connections are easy access * Requieres model specific addons* Brittle. * Option 2. * FSG005WNPB * $129.62/each * Link to product * Small in size * Low error percantage * Easy pin acces * More expensive * Small sensor base * Option 3. * FlexiForce A201 Sensor * $153.16/8pack * Link to product * Good weight tolerance * Great Temperature tolerance range * Lightweight * Only available in 8packs * Hard pin access

Choice: Option 1: Capacitive Force Sensor 8 mm 100 N (22 lbs)

Rationale: Our choice 1 (Capacitive Force Sensor) is the option chosen for three different reasons: price, style, and versatility. This option has the best price of the three, as one can only be purchased in packs of 8, and the other is quite expensive due to its precision and size. Second, the pin selection is exposed and easily accessible for soldering. In turn, its light weight and design are quite helpful for the model we want to produce, where the basket rests on the base of the sensor.

TL071ACP $0.77/eachlink to product *Inexpensive* Small in size * Connections are easy access * Cheap materials * Brittle. * Option 2. * MCP6S91-E/P * $1.30/each * Link to product * Small in size * Great temperature tolerance range * Programmable Gain * More likely to burn * Brittle * Option 3. * MCP6004-I/P * $0.59/each * Link to product * Previous experience with this model * Great Temperature tolerance range * Ideal voltage range * Limited to 4 circuits * Cheap Likely to burn

Choice: Option 3: MCP6004-I/P

Rationale: Our choice is option 3, since despite having previous experience with it, it also offers a greater number of circuits to assign in each respective system.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This schematic shows the complete circuit design for the light sensor subsystem. Figure 01 shows the nine sections that make up the light sensor subsystem. These are: the Curiosity Nano in the center, the light sensor in the horizontal rectangle in the upper left corner, the voltage regulator in the upper rectangle, the power supply for the Curiosity Nano in the rectangle to its right, the LED scale on the far right, the debugging push button in the lower right corner, the test LED to the left of the debugging button, and the ribbon cables below the Curiosity Nano.
